close_symbols: Daemon option flags: MHD_ALLOW_UPGRADE, MHD_USE_TLS, MHD_TEST_ALLOW_SUSPEND_RESUME

struct MHD_Daemon fields used: shutdown, worker_pool, new_connections_head, new_connections_tail, new_connections_mutex, urh_head, urh_tail, suspended_connections_head, suspended_connections_tail, connections_tail, resuming, itc, tid
explanation:
To determine whether any portion of close_all_connections is unreachable you must know both compile-time and run-time conditions and any operations that change list/link state or abort execution. The items above are necessary for that analysis: 

- The preprocessor feature symbols (UPGRADE_SUPPORT, HTTPS_SUPPORT, MHD_USE_THREADS, MHD_USE_POSIX_THREADS, MHD_USE_W32_THREADS, MHD_WINSOCK_SOCKETS) control whether large blocks of code are compiled at all; reachability depends first on which of these are defined.

- MHD_D_IS_USING_THREAD_PER_CONN_, MHD_D_IS_USING_THREADS_, and MHD_thread_handle_ID_is_current_thread_ determine the runtime booleans (e.g. used_thr_p_c) and are used in assertions/branches; knowing their semantics is required to decide if branches/loops can ever execute.

- The daemon option flags (MHD_ALLOW_UPGRADE, MHD_USE_TLS, MHD_TEST_ALLOW_SUSPEND_RESUME) are tested at runtime and enable/disable code paths (upgrade handling, TLS-specific shutdown, resume-suspend behavior). Their values affect reachability of many conditional blocks.

- The set of struct MHD_Daemon fields accessed by the function (shutdown, worker_pool, new_connections_*, urh_*, suspended_connections_*, connections_tail, resuming, itc, tid) are used as loop/branch guards or mutated; you need their types, initial/possible values and semantics to determine whether loops iterate, branches are entered, or lists are non-empty (i.e. whether code is executable).

- DLL_remove and new_connection_close_ (and other list-manipulation helpers like close_connection and MHD_cleanup_connections) mutate the linked lists the function traverses; understanding whether those operations can make loops progress or be no-ops is essential to rule out dead loops or unreachable loop bodies.

- process_urh, MHD_connection_finish_forward_, MHD_resume_connection and resume_suspended_connections affect the state transitions of upgraded/suspended connections; their behaviour (especially whether they can drop items into or remove items from lists) determines reachability of later cleanup code.

- MHD_mutex_lock_chk_ / MHD_mutex_unlock_chk_, MHD_thread_handle_ID_join_thread_, MHD_itc_activate_ and shutdown (system call) are synchronization/notification primitives that affect ordering and may cause threads to block/return; knowing whether they can block forever or abort influences whether subsequent code is reachable.

- mhd_assert, MHD_PANIC and MHD_DLOG can abort or otherwise alter control flow (panic likely terminates the process; asserts may be no-ops or abort depending on build). To judge whether code after an assert/panic is reachable you must know their semantics in the build.

- close_connection and MHD_cleanup_connections are finalizers called at the end; understanding whether they short-circuit, abort, or loop is necessary to see if any subsequent code is unreachable.

In short: feature macros (compile-time), the boolean macros/functions that compute used_thr_p_c and similar, the daemon option flags and the daemon structure fields that act as guards, plus the helper functions and macros that mutate lists, synchronize threads, or abort execution — all are required to establish whether any statement or block in close_all_connections can never be executed (and thus would violate the MISRA rule).
